docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Defense Secretary Ash Carter said on Thursday his occasional use of a personal email account for work-related matters was "a mistake" that he stopped a few months ago when it became clear to him it was against policy.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Defense Secretary Ash Carter used a personal email account for some government business in his first months at the Pentagon, the New York Times reported on Wednesday, citing White House and Defense Department officials and copies of the emails.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a Dec. 17 story about Defense Secretary Ash Carter's use of his personal email account, The Associated Press reported erroneously that Rep. Mac Thornberry said Carter should ask the Pentagon's Inspector General to verify that no classified information was transmitted over unsecured channels by Carter or Deputy Defense Secretary Robert Work. Thornberry referred to Carter's previous tenure as deputy defense secretary, but he made no mention of Work. Work's email practices are not in question.

docs.abstract: White House and Defense Department officials reveal Defense Secretary Ashton B Carter utilized his personal email account, in violation of Defense Department rules, during his first months at the Pentagon; email use of senior administration officials is closely watched after Hilary Clinton was found to have sent over 30,000 emails from her personal account while she was secretary of state.
